Student Guide to Marmoset Submit Server

 

Marmoset for students has two goals

 

1. To allow students to submit their code, where it is tested against a suite of tests written by the instructor. Test results can then be displayed and used by the student to improve their code.

 

2. To allow the instructor and/or TAs to view the code that students submitted, in order to help the student as well as to keep track of and look for patterns in the class’s code to improve the course.

 

Using the Submit Server

 

When working on programming projects, students will submit them to be tested by test cases written by the instructor.  There are three types of test cases: public tests, release tests, and secret tests.  Public tests are given to students at the beginning of the project, so students can see the source code and run them at any time.  Release tests are only run on the submit server; the results can only be seen if students spend a token, as explained in the next paragraph.  Secret tests are not shown at all -- the instructor may choose to make their results visible after the project deadline.

 

Tokens are meant to encourage students to start early in creating their programs. Unless a token is spent a student cannot see the release test results. After spending the token the number of passed and failed release tests is displayed, along with the names of the first two tests that failed. The token regenerates after a certain time, determined by the instructor, has passed.  For example, if the instructor gives students three tokens, with a 24-hour regeneration time, the student may not run release tests more than three times in any 24-hour period.

 

(Tokens, in other words, are a sadistic idea to torment students -- especially to create great anxiety as a student spends their last token to see if the program is fixed or not and the next token does not regenerate until after the deadline.)

 

Submit Server Interface

 

Project - Link to the project’s description

Submissions - Link to that project’s interface, which shows the different submissions sent in for that particular project

Web Submission - Links go to an interface where a .jar or .zip file of the project can be submitted incase the plug-in for the student’s IDE does not work

Download Starter Files - Lets the students download files that will be needed for that project if there are any. (If projects are located on a CVS Repository then the “Download Starter Files” link will most likely not be used.)

Due – Date project is due

Title – Title of project

 

Individual Project Submission Page

 

Submitted – Date submitted

Public Tests Score – Student score for public tests/Possible points for tests

Release Test Score – Displays a “?” unless a release token is spent for that submission, after token spent will display Student score for release tests/Possible points for tests

Release Tested - Date of when the token is spent

# Inconsistent Background Retests - The server runs the submission on the suite of tests more than once, if different results occur between runs number of inconsistent tests is displayed

Detailed Test Results – Leads to individual submissions page

Download - Download the code of that particular submission

 

Individual Submission Page

 

Code Coverage Results - Displays the amount of code that is checked over by Student tests and Public tests. (Students are encouraged to create their own tests that test as much of their code as possible.) This is shown as the fraction “how much the tests cover”/“how much there is in total”

Statements – Lines of code

Conditionals – Number of if statements in code (If number is low then certain branches of the code is not being checked.)

Methods – Number of methods in code

 

Student-written Test Results - Results of tests written by the student

 

These methods are not covered by a Public or student-written test

Class – Fully qualified name of class

Method – Method in class

Line Number – Code line in class

Link – Link to a page that displays the code of that class, with the method highlighted

 

Test Results - Shows the results of tests

Type – Type of test

Outcome – Possible outcomes of each test

Passed – test passed

Failed – test failed

Could not run – test case could not be executed, usually due to the submission could not be compiled

Timeout – test took to long and was stopped by server, usually by an infinite loop or the submission running very slowly

Error – (Java only) test failed due to an exception that occurred in the test

Not_implemented – (Java only) test failed because what testing for not implemented yet in student code

Source Coverage – Leads to separate page displaying the coverage of this particular test

Points – Points earned if pass test

Name – Name of test

Short Result – Short comment about test

Long Result – If test fails displays the stack trace

 

“See all test results for this submission” – Sometimes instructors have to change tests during a project. If test scores change due to the new tests this link appears. The link leads to a page that lets the student see the different results.
